We use a couple of time the valet'closet for ice, it was working well the first 2 times but the 3rd time we had no ice despite several trys They do have a free house car (Mercedes S, hybrid) but they don't market it and it seems that it's up the bellman to decide who you can use it (we were waiting for a cab for several minutes and someone arrived after us and the bellman encourage him to use the house car). The next day, we use the house car to see a show, the driver was from another time & world, when we arrive at the Wynn he begin to shout, in a very formal way to the Wynn'bellman : "Mrs & Mr Z... are going to see Le Reve" who cares ! It was almost funny We also visited one of their Presidential Suite, the Taipan, it was nice but really don't worth the money (about 7k). We were upgraded to a presidential suite at TheHotel some years ago and it was much nicer. As someone already said, if you want a room and a quiet hotel the MO may be the spot. If you're more a suite person go somewhere else.

Reviews.Title: “bring your wallet”
Reviews.Author: spurg
Reviews.Content: The pool area just opened when we checked in and we spent some time there. They offer some free pool items that the pool boys will hook you up with: water, fruit, cashews. A 5 dollar tip at the pool may be the smartest money you'll spend at this property as those same cashews run 12 dollars in your room! The pools and jacuzzis are beautifully designed trapezoidal shapes that are all heated to different temperatures.The way the buildings are configured, there is a venturi effect causing wind to funnel through the pool area. Stuff blows around a great deal -- the upside is that this may keep the guest cool during the summer months. Overall, this is the nicest pool area in Las Vegas and is in keeping with the vibe of the Mandarin. The spa is beautiful but pricey. A pedicure is 135$ I wanted to take a 15 minute steam at the spa but they wanted 100$. I passed and soaked in the room tub. They should cut that spa price in half. The room. If you like wood and asian influence, you'll dig the inerior look and feel. We booked this after staying at other vegas properties: Encore, Wynn, Belagio, Skylofts. It is nice not to have to walk through a smoke filled casino--even if your a big player, it is great to have an oasis of calm to stay in. The yoga room in this property is very cool. And it is worth staying at this poperty for the incredible service. They escort you to your room and cater to your every need. We were originally assigned room 1607 with a strip side view (of harley davidson and dingy polo towers) but Jing Li easily moved us to the back of the property overlooking the pool area (room 1732). It was very quiet on that side--if noise is an issue for you, i would get an even numbered room. The location of the Mandarin is a bit odd overlooking a really crumby section of the strip. You are very close to the self-parking lot, but it is a maze of paths and levels to get there. But hey, most will just valet their car anyway and pay the 30$. The self dimming lights and magical controls of the room are fun but take getting used to. Everything can be controlled with the TV remote and the TV screen menu. Turn down service is very nice. The room is very well designed and has some unique features that you should discover on your own. If money is not an issue, this is a great place to stay. If you are looking for a deal, the Encore has a nice suite for half the price. Would I rather stay here? Of course. We had dinner at MOzen and the Indian dishes are excellent and a good value. I was surprised by the beverage prices: 28 for a glass of champagne, 9 for a club soda and 9 for a cup of herbal tea. But the property itself is heaven. Very zen. All on a human scale. The city center: It's a mixed bag. Since Prada and most of the stores are opening in the fall of 2010, it is not fair to comment. Maestros restaurant is seriously an amazing design out of wood. It does not work like a real city because there is no ground level. Everything is on different levels and there is no logic to it. A real city has an inuitive feel that allows you to move from one location to another with ease. The city center is a confusing jumble of mazes, bridges, trams to nowhere, and confusing signage.

Reviews.Title: “winner”
Reviews.Author: meremom
Reviews.Content: We love it! It's so quiiet, high class. It's very comfortable. We didn't believe this hotel is in Las Vegas. It's a "winner".

Reviews.Title: “Excellence as standard at the Mandarin”
Reviews.Author: CWTraveller99
Reviews.Content: This hotel is superb. The rooms are stylish and luxurious. The hotel has fantastic views of the strip. However, what puts this hotel in a different class is the customer service. The staff are incredible and could not do more to assist. On one occasion when I asked for a taxi, instead I was taken in the MO private S class merc limo for free. The dining is also superb - whether in Twist, the Bistro or in-room dining. Indeed, the in-room dining proposition is the best I have ever enjoyed. My only regret is staying here as the first hotel of my holiday. It made all the other hotels (including Amangiri an Four Seasons Scottsdale) seem very average!

Reviews.Title: “Shhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhh, don't tell anyone.”
Reviews.Author: fourseasonslover
Reviews.Content: I think it's inevitable that this best of Vegas will be found soon, depending on what you want from Vegas this could or could not be what you're looking for. I'm not a big gambler so i like that this place was away from it all. I like being able to get away in Vegas and this is the place to do this in Vegas. The Service is 2nd to none, the only place that compares in Vegas to this is the Four Seasons. I think the service here was better but you can't go wrong at either one. I got a hell of a deal booked through American Express that really helped the value of this hotel, one that probably won't be around again. $205 per night, 3rd night free + $50 breakfast credit daily, + $200 room credit + $100 spa credit. Restaurant motif is spectacular, food is so good. I don't want to put to much down here that this review gets too long but give this place a try before the secret gets out and the room rates jump. When that happens it could be a little different. We stayed on a Sunday, Monday, Tuesday during slow period in Vegas so room rates were depressed. I'm not suprised to see that in just 4 months this place has already climbed about 180 spots on tripadvisor. By year end 2010 this place will most likely be #1 or #2 behind or in front of the four seasons. Ahhhhh the four seasons, to be in the same company as the four seasons you're doing alot of things right.

Reviews.Title: “Best on the Strip”
Reviews.Author: Jeff R
Reviews.Content: As a frequent business visitor to Las Vegas I have had the opportunity to stay at all of the finer Las Vegas hotels. There are some fabulous hotels along The Strip. A desire for something new and different prompted a change in favor of the new Mandarin Oriental at City Center. In a word, this hotel is FABULOUS! Rooms: While not the largest or most ornate rooms in Las Vegas, they do marry luxury and practicality in a previously unattained manner. From the butler locker to the Control 4 entertainment/comfort system the room designer maximized space and convenience. The modern room included a fully functional, nicely sized desk, a typically "over-the-top Vegas" bathroom, a lounge chair, and a pillow top mattress. The light switches were easy to locate and easier to use. The room was comfortable, luxurious, and practical. Physical Facility: The hotel is part of the massive City Center development between The Bellagio and The Monte Carlo. There is a casino about 1/4 mile away (In Aria). One does not have to walk through a casino and smell cigarette smoke to enter the hotel or the guest rooms. The hotel common areas are beautifully done. The spa is overwhelming in both scope and quality. The guest rooms are protected by an elevator security system which requires an active key in order to stop an elevator on a floor with rooms. This is becoming more common, but not yet standard in Las Vegas. The developers spent alot of money on this hotel and it shows. Bar/Restaurant: The bar is gorgeous and always had a buzz of activity. The bartenders made it tough to leave for other commitments. The drinks were of good quality and the winelist very well put together. While lacking depth (as is typical in a new establishment) it covered nearly all regions and varietals with at least one option. The glass list was also broad enough to cover most of the world's primary wine regions. The resaurant is beautiful and the food was fabulous. It was full on the Wednesday evening we visited. We enjoyed the tasting menu of six courses and a bottle each of white and red burgundy. It is on the level of the other "best in the world" French restaurants that have almost taken over the top-level dining scene in Las Vegas. Service: If the Mandarin is to succeed in the hyper-competitive Las Vegas hotel industry it will be because of the unprecedented level of service at this hotel. I travel frequently and generally stay in full service "luxury" hotels. The level of service I observed at this hotel is unmatched by competitors in the United States, including other Mandarin operated hotels. One needs to travel to a top property in Europe, India or Asia to experience the level of top-quality service I observed at this hotel. The friendly, professional, well trained staff is there at every turn. While the service was ready and willing, it did not "hover" and was not smothering. The men and women in management and on the staff at this hotel are to be commended for jobs well done. The only downside to this fantastic experience is the cost. It is significantly more expensive than its primary competitors. While "value" is always subjective, and I feel that the hotel was a good value for all it gives, other travelers may feel that they are being over-charged. The restaurant and bar are at the TOP level of pricing for Las Vegas. The spa treatment I enjoyed was likewise more expensive than any similar treatment I have received in Las Vegas. Having said that, all of these experiences exceeded the quality of other like-experiences, so, as I said, value will always be a subjective determination. Bottom line: Las Vegas now has a quiet, professional luxury hotel of un-equaled service for those who enjoy the fine touches and distinctions that make a hotel great vs. nearly great or very good. If that fine line matters to you then you have found a new home in Las Vegas. If these intricacies are of little value or you use the hotel primarily for sleep and little else then you will want to save your money and will do better at other high end properties.

Reviews.Title: “The Best!”
Reviews.Author: easton1
Reviews.Content: My husband and I stayed here in March 2010. The stay was flawless. The room was gorgeous and the service impeccable. If we can afford it, this hotel will always be our choice. I recommend the hotel without reservation.

Reviews.Title: “FANtastic. A true fan of the Mandarin”
Reviews.Author: gumjoytravels
Reviews.Content: I love the Mandarin Oriental hotel chain and a stay at their hotel in Las Vegas cemented my feelings towards them. This hotel is incredible, its brand new, everything is perfect. The hotel as a whole is a beautiful building with the most high-tech rooms I have ever experienced but all that flash would be worthless if it wasn't for the great staff who make your stay just that much more special. There are many hotel options in Vegas but i am happy i paid a little more than the average for such a great service.

Reviews.Title: “WOW! This is a MUST stay!!!”
Reviews.Author: Jorton
Reviews.Content: I have to say, I have stayed at a LOT of hotels, but this one takes the cake for quality & service. At the check-in desk on the 23rd floor, you are greeted with a Jasmine tea, with a cold refresh towel and a lovely orchid. You are escorted to your room rather than told how to find it, in fact whenever we asked where something was, we were taken rather than told. The bed just has to be the most comfortable I have found, along with huge down pillows. The room features are controlled from the TV or the LCD pad by the bed - Curtains, Lights, Temperature etc... Even your alarm clock can be set to open the curtains when it is time to get up. The bathroom is simply huge and is definitely a feature which makes the stay even better. I was disappointed at the breakfast we had at the 3rd floor restaurant and would eat somewhere else next time. The bar on the 23rd floor overlooks the strip and has an amazing array of custom cocktails; somewhat pricey, but the view and the drinks are superb. I was very pleased at the absence of a casino in the building, although the Monte Carlo is right next door (5 min walk). The interior of the hotel did not have any of that "Vegas" smell I associate with casinos and was a joy to stay at. I would highly recommend this hotel to anyone wanting to impress their spouse with VIP service or just want a great hotel. Pricing is on the higher side but an equivalent room in any of the other hotels would likely be similar, however this one was definitely value for money - you get what you pay for and then some.

Reviews.Title: “Well done Mandarin Oriental, well done...”
Reviews.Author: InstantNoodles
Reviews.Content: Well done Mandarin Oriental, well done. This is my first time staying at a Mandarin Oriental property and now I am a doting fan! For those visiting Las Vegas interested in spending $300 and up for a room, I would implore you to give the Mandarin Oriental a shot. It will be well worth it—the impeccable service should win you over. Considering the hotel has less than 400 rooms/suites (392 to be exact), the hotel can cater more to your needs than that of a mammoth casino hotel. The starting room category size is roughly 500 square feet but I would highly recommend guests to book the Mandarin Premier Room (about 650 square feet). Useful information about the hotel: I was happy that the hotel allowed us to check-in early and check-out a little past official check-out time; but notwithstanding that, check-in is 3’oclock and check-out is noon. The hotel is centrally located between the Monte Carlo another City Center hotel/casino. The hotel has a Mercedes S-Class Hybrid available on a first-come, first-serve basis to shuttle guests in style (limited-radius) to area hotels/casinos. Valet parking is $30 per night and a twin-sized rollaway is $150 (I am not sure if it’s per stay or per day, although I would assume the latter to be safe). When ordering room service the following taxes/service charges will apply: $5 delivery fee, 18% gratuity and local taxes… 2 orders of rice congee and smoked salmon/bagel was ~$58. On that note, taste wise, I found the food to be average—I was not wowed and it proved to just be a convenient option when you don’t have time to visit other dining establishments in Las Vegas. To access the guest quarters, you will need to go through two sets of elevators (for security purposes) and need your room key to access guest floors. The pool is scheduled in open in March 2010 and there is a fully-equipped gym open during regular business hours. There is an on-site spa/salon and from what I hear, MO properties are renowned for their spas so I imagine being a new property the spa is on par with that of its sister properties around the world-- I did not try the spa so I can't comment). The hotel’s website offers detailed information about the room /suite categories so I won’t bore you with the details. I will share what I found interesting about the Mandarin Premier Room that I booked. There is a valet closet in the hotel—basically a small closet to discretely hide shoes that you want shined (complimentary), find your morning newspaper, clothes returned that you had cleaned/pressed, and anything else you require from the hotel so it’s not hanging outside your door (convenient if you need something from housekeeping but do not want to immediately answer the door). The bathroom was the best feature of the room. Our bathroom was expansive and it seemed unnecessarily big. I liked how the toilet was separated from the shower/tub (separate) so that one person could use the toilet and the other could still shower without intruding on each other’s space. This feature is accomplished through the use of a series of locking doors. The closet was big too, enough to hold several days worth of clothes for two people. Bathroom amenities were Aromatherapy Associates and was designed with consultation with the hotel. There was a jewelry box that contained the useful toiletries. The selection of TV channels is varied and plentiful. Never have I came across a hotel with so many channels (channels in French, Russian, Chinese…and plenty of high-quality cable channels from US broadcasting stations). On a last note, everything is automated in the hotel (including the expensive mini-bar). There is a PDA that can control the entire function of the room/suite including lights, curtains, and A/C. Traditional guests can rest assured that there are still “manual” controls to operate those functions as well. To sum up the level of personalized service in one word: WOW. Being a first-time guest of the hotel and the brand in general, I was completely wowed by the superlative level of service provide to me and my travelling companions. I wanted to express kudos to both the Front Desk and Concierges at the hotel. They did a wonderful job anticipating our needs and exceeded our wildest expectations about seeing me through a vulnerable time. The ever-resourceful Concierge team did a great job pulling through last-minute requests for dining arrangements. FYI: some of the Concierges are members of Les Clef d’Or—which basically means that they are the best of the best in the industry and are at your full disposal when staying at the hotel. They were very personable and had excellent dining recommendations. If I had to be nit-picky, I would say there were several service deficiencies that I encountered. Housekeeping did not turn down my room even though I had asked for turndown to be performed during a set time period. Additionally, during peak times, calls were intermittently given the busy signal (i.e. to housekeeping) and were either routinely transferred to other departments or not answered (i.e. a call to Front Desk – not answered or a call to the Concierge, rolled to the Front Desk or Hotel Operator). There were glitches with the television intermittently freezing up and the A/C automatically resetting to a default temperature. Other than that, which I am sure the hotel will improve upon after settling into the locale that is Las Vegas, I would whole-heartedly recommend the hotel to everyone and anyone looking for a hotel to cater to their needs while enjoying all that Las Vegas has to offer.

Reviews.Title: “A truly unique Las Vegas experience”
Reviews.Author: brian714
Reviews.Content: One of a kind in Vegas. MO has brought a whole new experience to the strip. I love the fact that your right on the strip and can soak up all the action and gaming yet you can escape it all with an easy walk back to the tranquil and sophisticated MO. Rooms are spectacular and the service can't be beat. The staff here has one goal and that is to make you happy and make things right. One of the best spas in the world, I had my best massage ever here by Kimberly. Room service is anything but the norm, the food is excellent and the dining staff is very professional. I'm usually not big into room service but it was so easy and delicious I had it 3 times during my 3 night stay. Breakfast and dinner both get 5 out of 5 stars. The only thing I'd say that they work on is the housekeeping. We had no less than 5 knocks on the door during our stay asking when we wanted the room serviced, this was with the privacy notification on, we had another 4-5 phone calls asking the same. I almost forgot, the bathrooms are FAB, but the water pressure is borderline dripping. I was in a dynasty suite which also had a wonderful steam shower, but without good water pressure it made the rain shower worthless.

Reviews.Title: “They Deliver What They Promise”
Reviews.Author: JRWB1960
Reviews.Content: They promise elegance, peace and quiet and exceptional hospitality. This is exactly what they provide. Check in at Las Vegas hotels can be something like a Soviet bread line. Not so at MO. We were greeted in the 23rd floor lobby by 2 agents one engaging us in pleasant conversation and the other offering us jasmine tea and hot washcloths. Next we were shown to our room by the lead agent who was charming and professional. These employees are accessible genuine and friendly. There is nothing stuffy about them or the hotel for that matter. The room itself was a beautifully designed space of about 500 sq ft. Plenty of dark wood, marble and etched glass. Wonderful touches such as fresh flowers and a valet kit in the bathroom and an assortment of elegant stemware in the bar. The floor to ceiling windows offer views of the fake Eiffel Tower and the beautiful City Center. The beds are exceptional--you sink slowly into them when you lay down. There is calming accent lighting in the room and bathroom. There are bath salts provided for the deep soaking tub. Twice daily housekeeping was thorough and thoughtful. I brought travel size mouthwash which housekeeping noticed and kept replenishing the supply for me. Did I mention it was quiet? It was as serene as a temple in that room. Definitely an oasis in the middle of Las Vegas After exploring the City Center across the pedestrian bridge (which is another beautifully desinged space with shopping and dining) we had dinner at Twist on the 23rd floor. The hostess recognized us by sight. The check in agents knew our dinner plans and had briefed the restaurant staff on who we were, what we looked like and why we were there (birthday celebration--earlier she had a delicious chocolate cake sent to the room). We sat by the window which afforded a great city view. The care that goes into the food and service at Twist is fantastic. Again-it is not in the least bit stuffy or formal (although it is dressy). We were thoughtfully cared for without any hovering. Upon exiting Twist the same agent came over to us and inquired about our meal and then corralled us over to the M Bar for a final drink. Even though the place was crowded there was a couch and 2 chairs immediately available or us. The berry bellinis are excellent. The pricing here ($20/drink) keeps this from being a rowdy party place. Most people (including us) stayed or one round only. The view and design at M Bar are very special. I ordered breakfast to be delivered between 8:45 and 9. The doorbell rang at 8:45 precisely. How often does THAT happen in Las Vegas or anywhere? The coffee was piping hot and the juice was perfectly chilled. The pastries and fruit (with huge ripe blackberries) came with an assortment of butters and Viennese fruit preserves. They wheeled it all in on a table with an vase of flowers on it. Check out was equally as thoughtful as check in. No waiting--lots of personal attention. I don't think this is for people looking to be in the thick of things or for party animals looking for the "Vegas" experience. But for those more into relaxing a little bit it is perfect. I can't say enough about how luxurious this place is.

Reviews.Title: “The most luxurious rooms in Las Vegas and probably in the U.S.”
Reviews.Author: OLV_P
Reviews.Content: Impressive rooms - huge in size, ultra high tech, cosy, airy and bright Beds are heavenly ! The Mandarin Oriental Group has gone the extra mile in Las Vegas developing an exceptional property. As in all other locations, the Las Vegas Mandarin will surely become THE number ONE luxury hotel in the city. Despite being a non gaming property the Mandarin Oriental is likely to attract all the discerning customers, setting a new standard of luxury in Vegas. And it doesn't need to become a hot spot !...it would spoil the tranquility! Service cannot get any better ! Staff are genuinly warm and courteous, many of them showing how proud they are to work for such an incredible property.
